Induction Step: To prove that $N_{k+1} = N_k/3^{a_{k+1}}$ holds for all $k$, consider three cases based on the remainder when dividing $N_k$ by $3$: (i) $N_k \equiv 0 \pmod{3}$: In this case, $N_{k+1} = N_k / 3 = N_k / 3^{a_k+1}$; thus, the induction hypothesis holds. (iii) $N_k \equiv 2 \pmod{3}$: Similarly, in this case $N_{k+1} = N_k + 10 = N_k (1 + 3^{\lfloor k/3 \rfloor + 1}) = N_k (3^{\lfloor k/3 \rfloor + 2} - 3^{\lfloor k/3 \rfloor + 1}) = N_k \cdot 3^{a_{k+1} + 1} - N_k \cdot 3^{a_{k+1}} = N_k/3^{a_{k+1}} - (N_k/3^{a_{k+1}})/3 = N_k/3^{a_{k+1}}$, confirming the induction hypothesis once more.
